;;欧洲之星列车
;

;一家西班牙铁路公司宣布计划推出巴黎至伦敦高速列车 -竞争对手欧洲之星的高速列车服务。

;

;该公司 Evolyn 表示，该线路具有“战略性且需求量大”，并表示打算在 2025 年推出首条服务。该公司已达成协议，购买 12 条高速列车它补充说，法国制造商阿尔斯通的高速列车还可以选择购买另外四列。

;

;;Evolyn 告诉国际铁路公报，该服务将在巴黎北站和伦敦圣潘克拉斯国际机场之间直达，自新冠病毒危机以来，法国北部和英格兰南部那些被剥夺了欧洲之星服务的人们的希望破灭了。

;

;该公司表示，三年来一直在计划这项新服务（已投资 10 亿英镑），并且已经就使用铁轨进行了讨论。

;

;Evolyn 由西班牙 Cosmen 家族领导，该家族投资了长途汽车和火车公司 Mobico（前身为 National Express），并得到了未透露姓名的英国和法国的支持“金融合作伙伴”。

;

;“我们知道英国和法国政府欢迎一个项目，该项目将允许其公民增加英国与欧洲大陆几个国家之间的联系选择，并通过绿色Evolyn 首席执行官 Jorge Cosmen 说道。

;

;英吉利海峡隧道运营商 Getlink 对 Evolyn 计划申请成为巴黎第二家国际运营商的消息表示欢迎。伦敦线。该隧道网络的设计目标是每年运送超过 2000 万名旅客，是目前人数的两倍。 ;英国脱欧后边境检查< /a>; 导致服务减少。

;

;Getlink 总经理 Yann Leriche 表示，Evolyn 的公告“证实了欧洲隧道基础设施的经济和技术吸引力以及巨大的增长潜力

;

;欧洲之星国际有限公司 (EIL) 是唯一的客运运营商，以前称为欧洲之星，由英国、法国和比利时的三个独立公司拥有。 2014 年，英国政府以略高于 7.57 亿英镑的价格将其在 EIL 的全部权益出售给投资公司，一家在加拿大，另一家在美国。

;

;欧洲之星的目标，此后与高高速列车运营商Thalys预计到2030年每年运载3000万名乘客，而2019年欧洲之星和Thalys服务的乘客总数为1890万人次。该公司表示将考虑恢复车站停靠包括阿什福德国际机场和艾贝斯费特国际机场，但预计在可预见的将来火车不会在其中任何一个停靠。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 23:52:02 +0800 ‘Streets on the moon’: lunar dust could be ‘melted’ to make solid roadshttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/12/streets-on-the-moon-lunar-dust-could-be-melted-to-make-solid-roads
;;2023-10-12T15:00:12Z;
;
;;月球
;

;月球没有空气，没有水，极端温度为 250 度范围，但对于希望建立营地的航天机构来说，最棘手的挑战之一是灰尘。它会腐蚀宇航服、堵塞机械、干扰科学仪器并使移动变得困难。

;

;现在科学家们提出了一个潜在的解决方案，证明可以使用巨大的透镜融化月球尘埃以形成坚固的道路和着陆区。

;

;“你可能会想：‘月球上的街道，谁需要它？’”柏林联邦材料研究与测试研究所 (BAM) 的 Jens Günster 教授及其同事说道。关于可能的解决方案的报告的作者。 “但事实上，即使在早期，这也是一种令人沮丧的需求。它是非常松散的物质，没有大气层，重力很弱，所以灰尘到处都是。它不仅污染你的设备，还污染其他国家的设备。没有人会乐意被另一枚火箭的灰尘覆盖。”

;
;

;;相关：;;美国宇航局官员表示，到 2030 年，宇航员将在月球上生活和工作;

;
;

;灰尘已经此前的任务曾遭受过严重破坏，例如月球勘测者 III 号航天器（因阿波罗 12 号着陆时扬起的灰尘而损坏），克服这一挑战是美国宇航局的首要任务，其目标是建立一个永久的月球前哨站。将建筑材料运送到月球的成本太高，因此需要非常规的解决方案。

;

;“你需要使用那里的东西，而那只是松散的灰尘，”Günster 说。

;

;他和同事对一种名为 EAC-1A 的细粒材料进行了实验，该材料由欧洲航天局开发，作为月球土壤的替代品。他们使用直径 50 毫米的激光束将灰尘加热到约 1,600 摄氏度并将其熔化。他们慢慢地描绘出了弯曲的三角形，每个三角形的直径约为 25 厘米，这些三角形可以相互连接，在大面积的月球土壤上形成固体表面，作为未来的道路和着陆场。

;

;这个过程并不快。每个小几何单元的制作大约需要一个小时，这意味着创建一个 10 x 10m 的着陆点需要大约 100 天的时间。 “这听起来像是永远，但想想地球上的建筑，”冈斯特说。 “有时需要很长时间才能建立一个新的交汇处。”

;

;为了在月球上重现这种方法，作者计算出需要从地球运输一个约 2.37 平方米的透镜来充当太阳光集中器代替激光。该镜片可以由可卷起的聚合物箔制成，使其易于运输。但灰尘仍然是镜头本身的一个问题。 “当镜头上积满灰尘时，它迟早会不再发挥作用，”Günster 说道，并补充说振动镜头可能有助于缓解这个问题。研究结果发表在;科学报告;杂志上。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 23:22:02 +0800 Zimbabwe FA investigating women’s team coach over sexual misconduct allegationshttps://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/oct/12/zimbabwe-fa-investigating-womens-team-coach-over-sexual-misconduct-allegations
;;2023-10-12T15:08:57Z;
;
;;津巴布韦足协的徽章和位于哈拉雷的国家体育场。
;

;津巴布韦足协(Zifa) 已证实，正在调查其高级女子教练团队的一名成员，指控其对女同事进行不当性行为。

;

;《卫报》了解到，这些指控与据称在该项目期间发生的一系列事件有关。南非正在进行的南部非洲足球协会理事会（Cosafa）女子锦标赛。其中包括声称教练不恰当地邀请他进入他的房间并“索要性恩惠”——这些指控首先是在 ;伦敦记者 Melody Gwenyambira 本周发表的一篇文章;。

;

;“津巴布韦足协已收到关于高级女性技术团队，”周四的 Zifa 声明中写道。 “这次旅行有一名高素质的安保人员陪同，他正在现场调查此事。

; ;

;“该协会对此事持悲观态度，目前正在进行独立调查，以查明指控的真相。提醒公众，这是一个敏感话题，他们不应采取可能影响调查的毫无根据的步骤。”

;

;Gwenyambira 表示，这些指控引发了对受影响者心理健康的严重担忧。 。据说，技术团队的一名女性成员在公开场合受到“言语骚扰和侮辱”后，在一次团队会议上流着泪离开。据了解，她没有与球队其他成员一起吃饭，试图避开被指控的教练，尽管这些指控在周二被公开，但该教练仍留在同一家酒店。

;

;津巴布韦被禁止参加国际比赛在津巴布韦政府因财务违规和技术人员对女裁判性骚扰的指控而暂停 Zifa 的资格后，国际足联暂停了近 18 个月的足球比赛。去年 9 月，Zifa 裁判委员会前秘书长奥伯特·佐亚 (Obert Zhoya) ;经《卫报》调查，被判犯有性骚扰女官员罪;，并被禁止在五年内从事所有与足球相关的活动。

;

;津巴布韦的禁令是7 月份取消了该协议，但 Zifa 仍处于正常化委员会的控制之下，该委员会的任务是重组该组织。根据国际足联的声明; 确认津巴布韦在 7 月取消禁令，还将在政府和 Zifa 之间建立合作协议，“该协议将明确各方的责任和目标，包括性骚扰主题”。

;

;据了解，国际足联的保障和儿童保护团队已与正常化委员会成员取得联系，要求提供有关 Zifa 调查的更多信息。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 23:22:02 +0800 Spain’s World Cup win was part of battle for equality, says Jenni Hermosohttps://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/oct/12/spains-world-cup-win-was-part-of-battle-for-equality-says-jenni-hermoso
;;2023-10-12T15:04:58Z;
;
;;8 月赢得女子世界杯后，埃尔莫索（中）与队友 Alexia Putellas（左）和 Irene Paredes。< /div>;

;西班牙足球运动员珍妮·埃尔莫索 (Jenni Hermoso) 在她的首次公开讲话中表示，西班牙世界杯的胜利是一场“更人性、更超越”的平等之战的一部分，因为她的球队的胜利被一个不请自来的吻所掩盖。

;

;该演讲是在墨西哥举行的一次活动中发表的，埃尔莫索为墨西哥足球俱乐部效力;帕丘卡;，其中有一个;致敬; 世界冠军。这位 33 岁的球员首先描述了她与队友一起举起世界杯奖杯时的情绪。

;

;“我一直想知道那天晚上我们到底做了什么，”她告诉观众。 “我们赢得了冠军，我们闻名世界，成为历史上最好的球队之一，但在内心深处，我们取得了更人性化、更超越的成就。”

;

;;La 的庆祝活动Roja; 的成就;当时的国家足协主席路易斯·鲁维亚莱斯的举动很快让她黯然失色，他抓住了赫莫索的头，将她拉向自己，并在她的嘴唇上印下一吻。颁奖典礼期间。

;

;随着西班牙各地的愤怒情绪高涨，许多人发现无法解开;鲁比亚莱斯的行为;来自 ;西班牙女足球运动员遭受了数十年的系统性歧视。

;

;埃尔莫索在周三的讲话中暗示了这场旷日持久的斗争。 “我们成为冠军并不是为了举起一个可以留在展示柜中的奖杯，或者获得奖金，或者出现在随着时间的推移而起皱的数千本[杂志]封面上，”她说。 “我们成为世界冠军，因为这是我们被倾听、尊重和重视的唯一方式。”

;

;赢得世界杯近两个月后，她赞扬了;La Roja; 改变了许多人看待女子足球的方式。 “我确信，世界各地数以百万计的女孩认同这群勇敢、忠诚和可敬的球员，并感受到他们的保护，他们的每一步都在思考所有这些女孩的未来，”她说。

;

;她承认，争取平等的斗争付出了个人的代价。她说：“也许我们牺牲了一些欢乐，一些庆祝活动，而且，在这个历史性时刻，我们不应该承受比我们应得的更多的痛苦。”溢出到对性别歧视的;更广泛的考虑;以及在工作场所滥用权力。全国各地的人们宣称：;;Se Acabó;;;，; 意思是“结束了”，正如足球联合会;撤回了对卢比亚莱斯的支持;，女足国家队教练是;被解雇;，以及 Hermoso ;提起刑事诉讼;，指控鲁维亚莱斯性侵犯。

;

;鲁比亚莱斯多次表示，这个吻是双方自愿的。他在一份声明中表示：“我相信真理，我将尽我所能，让真理获胜。” ;上个月他辞职了;。

;

;赫尔莫索指出她和团队承担着“巨大的责任”为子孙后代承载。 “对于所有那些没有扩音器让自己的声音被听到的人，我想说，这场战斗属于我们所有人，”她说。 “我们在场上和场外获胜，以确保体育和社会的包容性并保护我们所有人。”

;

;她在结束演讲时对从塞维利亚到接受的主题标签表示认可。西班牙足球俱乐部桑坦德银行正努力应对#MeToo 时刻。 “我想对所有人说：;Se acabó;，”她说。 “我是 Jenni Hermoso，我是一名足球运动员，我是那个成为世界冠军的女孩。”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 23:22:02 +0800 Philip Morris lobbying to stop WHO ‘attack’ on vapes and similar productshttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/12/philip-morris-lobbying-to-stop-who-attack-on-vapes-and-similar-products
;;2023-10-12T14:00:13Z;
;
;;菲利普莫里斯 IQOS 电子烟
;

;菲利普莫里斯国际公司 (PMI)，烟草和电子烟一封泄露的电子邮件显示，万宝路香烟背后的公司正在开展大规模游说活动，以阻止各国作为全球条约的一部分打击电子烟和类似产品。

;

;该公司越来越关注随着各国政府加强对卷烟的监管，无烟产品在 2022 年从加热烟草和电子烟等产品中获得了 101.9 亿美元（83 亿英镑）的收入。

;

;在 PMI 高级副总裁发送的消息中，上个月，《卫报》看到，外交部长特朗普的工作人员被告知，要在来自 182 个国家的代表开会之前寻找“任何联系、任何线索，无论是政治上的还是技术上的”。他将世界卫生组织会议的议程描述为对无烟产品的“禁止主义攻击”。

;

;对电子烟产品的审查越来越严格，;英国部长们迈出了英格兰禁止糖果色一次性电子烟的第一步;。已经就打击年轻人吸电子烟的计划启动了咨询;并完全禁止吸烟;，打造第一批“无烟一代”。卫生部长史蒂夫·巴克莱本月表示，他对过去三年中使用电子烟的儿童数量增加两倍的数据感到担忧。

;

;世界卫生组织烟草控制框架公约 (FCTC)，该公约下个月在巴拿马举行，将讨论对无烟产品可能进行的监管，包括税收。

;

;在电子邮件中，PMI 表示已经看到了大会的议程，该议程重点关注无烟产品。 2016 年，该烟草公司宣布将其业务从卷烟转型，并设定目标以加热烟草产品、电子烟产品和尼古丁袋取代卷烟。

;

;2022 年，PMI 售出 6210 亿支卷烟，根据其年度业绩。然而，其约三分之一的收入来自无烟产品，而可燃烟草产品的销量下降了 27%。

;

;其电子烟品牌包括 IQOS、Bonds 和 Veev，并推出了首款一次性电子烟。 PMI 对外事务高级副总裁 Grégoire Verdeaux 于 9 月 22 日发送的电子邮件称：“议程和会议文件已公开为主要部分。不幸的是，他们再次证实了我们的每一个担忧，即这次会议可能仍然是烟草控制历史上错失的最大机会……世卫组织的议程无非是对无烟产品进行系统性、有条理的、禁止性的攻击。”

;

;维多写道，如果没有“合理的、建设性的成果”，“世界卫生组织将不可逆转地损害公共卫生的历史性机遇，因为认识到无烟产品在适当监管下可以比烟草控制的总和更快地加速吸烟率下降” .

;

;他表示，在过去 18 个月里，他的公司一直致力于在会议上“利用正确的支持”，但他补充道：“现阶段我们还没有达到我们想要的目标 – 就目前而言情报、立场和代表团。”维多表示，当他们“真正下定决心”时，他们就能“取得进展”。他敦促道：“还有时间。”

;

;电子邮件继续说道：“因此，这封邮件要求您，作为 EA [外部事务] 职能的负责人，做出最后一刻的努力。每个国家，无论大小，都很重要”。 Verdeaux 表示，它已准备好“建立任何联系、任何线索，无论是政治上的还是技术上的，包括来自我们当地业务合作伙伴的联系”，这些合作伙伴往往“在我们较小的市场中发挥着关键作用”。

;

;烟草公司维多表示，尽管如此，他仍将前往巴拿马“公开谴责被排除在外的荒谬行为，而今天的 PMI 无疑是世卫组织在打击吸烟方面最有帮助的私人合作伙伴”。他在电子邮件的结尾写道：“无论发生什么，我们都站在历史的正确一边。但如果我们让禁酒主义者为所欲为，这将是一个小小的安慰。”

;

;“时间至关重要”，他说，这对成年吸烟者和“我们的生意将是重大的”。

;

;当被问及泄露的电子邮件时，维多在一份声明中表示：“我公开所说的话和我对员工所说的话完全相同：我很自豪能够向政府和媒体证明创新驱动更快地降低吸烟率，因此应该得到支持和监管。世界卫生组织《烟草控制框架公约》会议是闭门举行的，但应该是一个开放的论坛，科学家、消费者和公司也能发表意见。我将在巴拿马现场，并很高兴邀请任何人与我公开讨论这个问题。”

;

;人们越来越担心使用电子烟的年轻人数量不断增加。在英国，主要医生和委员会对部长们准备禁止一次性电子烟的报道表示欢迎。

;

;皇家儿科和儿童学院注册官 Steve Turner 教授 ;健康;，说他的英国同事“非常担心”年轻人吸电子烟。他补充说，电子烟是“有效戒除尼古丁成瘾和吸烟的方法”。他说，这种情况是“一场公共卫生灾难”，“儿童不应该对尼古丁上瘾”。

;

;澳大利亚禁止所有未经处方的电子烟，德国禁止调味电子烟，新西兰则< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/jun/06/new-zealand-to-introduce-new-rules-to-crack-down-on-youth-vaping">;取缔大多数一次性产品电子烟;并限制向儿童进行营销。本月，法国还宣布计划禁止所有一次性电子烟-香烟;。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 22:22:01 +0800 Sam Bankman-Fried’s lawyers to cross-examine Caroline Ellison in fraud trialhttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/12/sam-bankman-fried-ftx-trial-caroline-ellison-cross-examination
;;2023-10-12T13:00:10Z;
;
;;Caroline Ellison 于 10 月 11 日在纽约 Bankman-Fried 欺诈案审判中作证后离开联邦法院。
;

;;卡罗琳·埃里森; 在 ;Sam Bankman-Fried;' 的令人震惊的证词对;数十亿美元欺诈指控;的审判周四进入第三天， - 考试正式开始。

;

;28 岁的埃里森是对冲基金 Alameda Research 的首席执行官，也是班克曼-弗里德有时的女友，也是检方的;曼哈顿联邦法院审判中的明星证人;。 31 岁的 Bankman-Fried 面临七项与其管理加密货币交易所 FTX 相关的欺诈和共谋指控。他不认罪。

;
;

;;相关：;;卡罗琳·埃里森 (Caroline Ellison) 表示，在 FTX 倒闭后，她感到“如释重负，不必再撒谎了”;

;
;

;Bankman-Fried 的律师在之前的听证会上表示，他们打算追究可能损害埃里森的问题，将她描绘成一个被抛弃的前任和一个愚蠢的女商人。辩方向其他证人询问班克曼-弗里德要求埃里森对冲阿拉米达的财务状况以应对市场低迷的情况，但她没有履行这一要求。

;

;埃里森周三提供了阿拉米达不稳定的内部运作的详细年表，深深地印证了这一点。与 FTX 交织在一起，在 2022 年 5 月加密货币下跌后，这两家公司都因 100 亿美元赤字的拖累而崩溃。

;

;虽然首席执行官埃里森一直担心阿拉米达（主要由贷款资助）将被处理如果贷款人决定收取费用，而他们确实这样做了，那将是致命的打击。阿拉米达发现自己短缺数十亿美元。据埃里森称，该对冲基金在未通知客户的情况下非法使用 FTX 客户的资金来偿还债务，这是在班克曼-弗里德的指示下进行的。

;

;在她的证词中，埃里森详细介绍了她和班克曼-弗里德的黑暗关系，描述了这种纠缠如何让她感到悲伤并对她的工作产生了负面影响。

;她说，在通过 Google 文档发送给班克曼-弗里德的消息中，“我经常表达对我们的关系不满意的感受”。埃里森说，当加密货币崩盘开始时，两人就分手了，尽管一起经营企业，但她一直避免与他说话。

;埃里森周三表示，班克曼-弗里德将阿拉米达的垮台归咎于她。 2022 年 8 月，也就是他们分手几个月后，她和 Bankman-Fried 正在他们价值 4000 万美元的巴哈马顶层公寓的书房里进行商务对话，他们与其他 FTX 和对冲基金员工合住。

;

;“我们最初从谈论阿拉米达的资产负债表开始，然后萨姆开始说……这是一个很大的错误，这是我的错，我对阿拉米达所处的财务状况负有主要责任，”埃里森说。不过，她补充说，她记得班克曼-弗里德控制了阿拉米达的大部分投资决策。

;

;她在证人席上哭泣，还描述了随着时间的流逝，欺骗对她造成的压力 - 如果发生了什么事人们发现 FTX 客户资金正在支撑陷入困境的 Alameda？周三，她表示，如果太多 FTX 客户一次性提取资金，却发现自己无法实际收款，会发生什么情况？

;

;当 FTX 和 Alameda 确实在 2022 年 11 月倒闭时，她感到如释重负。< /p>;

;“那一周我的情绪波动很大，有很多不同的感受，但我的感受之一是一种压倒性的解脱感，”埃里森作证说。 “这是我长期以来一直害怕的事情……我只是感到一种解脱，因为我不必再撒谎了……我可以承担责任。”

;

; Ellison 承认因在 FTX 和 Alameda 倒闭中所扮演的角色而犯有电汇欺诈和共谋指控。 FTX 联合创始人 Gary Wang 同意类似的认罪协议，并于上周出庭指控 Bankman-Fried。

;;Gianluca Grimalda
;

;一位拒绝遵守雇主短途飞行要求的气候研究员从所罗门群岛发回德国的通知称，他已被解雇。

;
;

;;相关：;;拒绝飞行让我失去了气候研究员的工作。这是一个值得付出的代价;

;
;

;经过六个月的调查，吉安卢卡·格里马尔达仍在布干维尔等待一艘将于周六出发的货船，开始返回欧洲的旅程气候崩溃和全球化对岛上居民的影响。

;

;十多年来一直避免乘坐飞机的格里马尔达说，他已经向他在实地工作中遇到的人们做出了承诺——其中一些人已经流离失所由于海平面上升，他将在返程途中最大限度地减少碳排放。

;

;“IfW 似乎忽视了我们已经进入人类世时代，并且最重要的地球生态系统已接近崩溃，如果格里马尔达告诉《卫报》。

;

;“在这个时代，浪费 4.5 吨二氧化碳（飞行排放量和慢速旅行排放量之间的差值）来满足物理上的荒谬要求。在如此短的时间内出现在基尔在道德上是不可接受的，并且体现了全球精英的终极特权。

;

;“这表明 IfW 仍然生活在一个将被即将到来的气候崩溃所消灭的时代.”

;

;;周四，格里马尔达在《卫报》的评论部分撰文;指出，他从所罗门群岛飞往欧洲的单程航班所排放的碳量比居住在那里的普通人一整年的消耗量还要多。

;

;格里马尔达表示，他打算对独立工会解雇他的决定提出上诉，并表示他已向工会寻求帮助。 But, he added: “In this case, the initial impression is that IfW actions are justified legally.”

;

;A spokesperson for IfW told the Guardian it stuck by its policy of not discussing or commenting on staff issues in public. “In general, the institute encourages and supports its staff to travel climate-friendly,” the spokesperson said. “We are committed to do without air travel in Germany and in other EU countries as far as we can. When flights are unavoidable, we pay to ;Atmosfair; to offset flight emissions through climate protection projects.

;

;“What is public and obvious: Dr Grimalda planned his trip to Papua and his research stay with our support. We supported a second 'slow travel' trip of his before. So we have no general reservations about slow traveling.”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 20:52:01 +0800 Dominica may have sold thousands more ‘golden passports’ than it disclosed, analysis suggestshttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/12/dominica-golden-passports-citizenship-by-investment-cbi-scheme
;;2023-10-12T11:42:29Z;
;
;;Dominica passports
;

;The Caribbean island of Dominica may have sold thousands more “golden passports” than its government has publicly disclosed, according to analysis that raises questions about the transparency and governance of its $1bn (£822m) citizenship by investment scheme.

;

;An investigation by the Guardian and 14 other international news organisations, in partnership with the ;Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project;, has conducted the ;first detailed examination; of the identities and numbers of individuals who paid for Dominican citizenship.

;

;By scouring libraries and archives for copies of the government's Dominica Official Gazette, which is only available on paper and has not been digitised, reporting partners found 7,700 names declared in public records since 2007. New citizens were named in the gazette up to December 2018 and no names have been published since.

;

;Analysis of government budget data suggests as many as 19,000 individuals may have obtained citizenship between 2016 and 2022. Most passports were sold after 2015, when the EU introduced visa-fee travel for Dominican citizens, sparking a jump in sales from hundreds per year to thousands.

;

;The figures include some individuals naturalised via marriage or immigration, but the vast majority are thought to have paid for citizenship.

;

;Adding 19,000 new citizens would place Dominica among the biggest sellers of second nationalities, alongside Turkey and the Caribbean island of St Kitts, according to government declarations collated by Kristin Surak, an associate professor of political sociology at the London School of Economics.

;

;Dominica golden passport buyers can either pay $100,000 a head in a non-refundable donation to the government, or invest $200,000 in a local business. The scheme accounts for more than half of government revenues and has been key to funding jobs, housing, health and education.

;

;Dominica's government did not respond directly to detailed requests for comment on the numbers of people who obtained citizenship by investment.

;

;The prime minister, Roosevelt Skerrit, defended the scheme in two press conferences held after being approached by the Guardian and other publications for comment, describing the background checks on passport applicants as “robust”, with candidates undergoing “layers of due diligence”.

;

;Thomson Fontaine, leader of the opposition Union Workers Party, is a former IMF economist who has campaigned for years for greater accountability on the scheme. He responded to the latest concerns, saying: “The problem is that there is an absolute lack of transparency in the way passports are granted and the checks that are carried out on applicants.

;

;“Some people who have received passports are nowhere to be found officially. There is no transparency about how passports are obtained. The accounts presented by the CBI are incomplete.”

;

;The investigation's estimate of the number of passports sold come from analysis of Dominica's official budget documents. Dominica charges ;“Naturalisation Certificate Fees”; for every successful golden passport application. The fee was reduced in October 2017 from $750 to $250 per applicant.

;

;The ;budgets; appear to have reported naturalisation certificate fee income from the 2016/17 financial year, in a line item labelled as “Certificate of Naturalization (CBI)”.

;

;The documents show nearly 8m East Caribbean dollars ($3m) in fees in the ;2016/17; and ;2017/18; financial years, a figure that suggests 3,961 people naturalised during those two years alone, if the budget figures are correct. This is more than twice the 1,664 names published in the official gazettes for the period.

;

;Between 2016 and 2022 the reported naturalisation fees add up to 16m East Caribbean dollars ($6m), a figure that, when taking into account the fee reduction, suggests 19,000 people became naturalised citizens in that period.

;

;The official budgets also show that sales of passports surged after 2015 when Dominica, along with a number of other Caribbean countries, was granted visa-free travel to most EU member states for up to 90 days a year. The UK followed suit later.

;

;The UK withdrew visa-free travel for citizens of Dominica and a number of other states which sell citizenship last year, citing national security concerns. However, access to the EU remains unchanged.

;

;Any government has the legal right to set its own standards on who becomes a citizen. Dominican passports are popular with Chinese, Russian and Iranian nationals, who often face restrictions when crossing borders, registering businesses or opening bank accounts in western countries.

;

;Surak, the author of ;The Golden Passport;, a book about the schemes, said: “In a lot of countries, the data are not as clearly reported as they should be. It can be challenging to get basic numbers and sometimes they don't always add up.”

;

;“It varies country to country, and it also varies over time,” she said, citing improvements in schemes operated by Malta, Grenada and St Lucia. “Compared to some other countries, Dominica leans toward the 'having issues' side of the spectrum.”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 19:52:02 +0800 Human rights experts warn against European crackdown on climate protestershttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/12/human-rights-experts-warn-against-european-crackdown-on-climate-protesters
;;2023-10-12T11:00:08Z;
;
;;A demonstrator is detained during a climate protest last month in The Hague in the Netherlands
;

;Human rights experts and campaigners have warned against an intensifying crackdown on climate protests across Europe, as Guardian research found countries across the continent using repressive measures to silence activists.

;

;In Germany, France, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and the UK, authorities have responded to climate protests with mass arrests, the passing of draconian new laws, the imposing of severe sentences for non-violent protests and the labelling of activists as hooligans, saboteurs or eco-terrorists.

;

;The crackdowns have come in spite of calls by senior human rights advocates and environmental campaigners to allow civic space for the right to non-violent protest, after a summer of record-breaking heat in southern Europe that is attributed to the effects of climate breakdown.

;

;The UK has led the way in the crackdown, experts say, with judges recently refusing an appeal against multi-year sentences for climate activists who blocked a motorway bridge in east London. The three-year jail terms for Marcus Decker and Morgan Trowland earlier this year are thought to be the longest handed out by a British judge for non-violent protest.

;

;The ruling came as protesters in the UK try to navigate a new legal environment that includes significant limits on the right to protest, including two wide-ranging new laws passed in the past two years giving police the discretion to ban protests regarded as “disruptive” and criminalising a host of protest tactics.

;

;Michel Forst, the UN rapporteur on environmental defenders since June last year, described the situation in the UK as “terrifying”. He added that other countries were “looking at the UK examples with a view to passing similar laws in their own countries, which will have a devastating effect for Europe”.

; ;

;“Since my appointment I have been travelling to many countries in Europe and there is a clear trend,” Forst told the Guardian. “We can see an increasing number of cases by which these climate activists are brought to court more and more often and more and more severe laws being passed to facilitate these attacks on defenders.”

;

;He added: “I'm sure that there is European cooperation among the police forces against these kinds of activities. My concern is that when [governments] are calling these people eco-terrorists, or are using new forms of vilifications and defamation … it has a huge impact on how the population may perceive them and the cause for which these people are fighting. It is a huge concern for me.”

;

;Amnesty International said it was investigating a continent-wide crackdown on protest. Catrinel Motoc, the organisation's senior campaigner on civil space and right to protest in Europe, said: “People all around the world are bravely raising their voices to call for urgent actions on the climate crisis but many face dire consequences for their peaceful activism.

;

;“Peaceful protesters are left with no choice but to stage public protests and non-violent direct actions because European countries are not doing enough to tackle the climate crisis.

;

;“There's alarming evidence of criminalisation, harassment, stigmatisation and negative rhetoric towards environmental defenders.”

;

;Motoc said that instead of demonising and restricting peaceful environmental defenders, “European governments should put [their] energy into open dialogue with activists and organisations to fix the problems of climate crisis. Climate protesters are not a nuisance, and they should not be silenced or crushed.”

;

;In June, Dunja Mijatović, the Council of Europe's commissioner for human rights, also called for an end to crackdowns on environmental activists. Last December, Volker Türk, the UN's high commissioner for human rights, appealed to governments to protect the “civic space” for young environmental activists, and “not crack down in a way that we have seen in many parts of the world”.

;

;There was widespread outrage this summer when France's interior minister, Gérald Darmanin, used one of the state's most-powerful tools to order the banning of one of the country's leading environmental protest groups.

;

;Les Soulévements de la Terre, a collective of local environmental campaigns, had staged a series of protests, with tactics including sabotage, that ended with violent confrontations with police, and Darmanin denouncing the activists as “far left” and “ecoterrorists”.

;

;In the Netherlands, one of a series of roadblock protests on the A12 highway in The Hague in May was dispersed by police using water cannon, with more than 1,500 arrested. Seven climate activists were convicted of sedition – a charge that had never before been levelled against climate protesters – in relation to online posts calling for people to join an earlier demonstration.

;

;In Sweden, about two dozen members of the Återställ Våtmarker [Restore Wetlands] group were convicted of sabotage for blocking highways in the capital, Stockholm. Others were held on remand for up to four weeks for taking part in protests.

; ;

;In Germany in May, police staged nationwide raids against the Letzte Generation (Last Generation) group, whose supporters had glued themselves to roads on a near-weekly basis for months, as well as targeting art galleries and other cultural spaces. On a police directive, the homepage of the group was shut down and possessions belonging to members were seized.

;

;At the most recent count, supplied by the activists, police had made more than 4,000 arrests of supporters of Last Generation taking part in road blocks in Berlin alone.

;

;Authorities in Italy have ;used anti-organised crime laws; to crack down on protests, where the Ultima Generazione (also Last Generation) group has staged road blocks since last year. The Digos police unit, which specialises in counter-terrorism, in April justified the use of anti-Mafia laws to target the group by saying its civil disobedience actions had not taken place spontaneously, but were organised, discussed and weighed up by an internal hierarchy. This came along with new, stiffer penalties for protests, with activists facing fines of up to €40,000 for actions targeting artworks and other cultural heritage.

;

;Richard Pearshouse, director of the environment division at Human Rights Watch, said: “These restrictions on environmental protest across Europe and the UK are incredibly short-sighted. These governments haven't grasped that we all have a huge interest in more people taking to the streets to demand better environmental protection and more climate action.

;

;“Governments need to respect the rights to assembly and expression, and ramp up their own environmental protections and climate ambitions. That's the only way we have a chance to get out of this climate crisis with our democratic institutions intact.”

;

;A spokesperson for the UK Home Office said: “The right to protest is a fundamental part of our democracy but we must also protect the law-abiding majority's right to go about their daily lives.

;

;“The Public Order Act brings in new criminal offences and proper penalties for selfish, guerrilla protest tactics.”

;

;The French interior ministry said local officials had the right to ban demonstrations with a serious risk of disturbing public order. “These one-off bans, of which there are very few in absolute terms, are not imposed because of the reason for the demonstration.”
;
; The Italian interior ministry referred to a statement from the culture minister Gennaro Sangiuliano in April, who said attacks on monuments cause economic damage to the community that is is expensive to clean up. “Those who cause damage must pay personally.”
;
; The German interior ministry declined to comment. The Bavarian interior ministry referred the Guardian to the public prosecutor's office in Munich, which provided a statement from June in which it confirmed it had authorised the tapping of phones for six of seven Last Generation members under criminal investigation.

;

;The Swedish interior ministry declined to comment. The Dutch ministry of justice did not respond to requests for comment.

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 19:22:01 +0800 Australians look set to vote against Indigenous voice in parliamenthttps://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/oct/12/australians-look-set-to-vote-against-indigenous-voice-in-parliament
;;2023-10-12T09:54:48Z;
;
;;The Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, clasping the hand of senior traditional owner Reggie Uluru in front of Uluru.
;

;Australians look set to reject a referendum proposal to recognise Indigenous people in the constitution by creating a body to advise parliament, with ;polls showing a clear majority for no in almost all states ;before Saturday's vote.

;

;To be accepted, the proposal needs to achieve a majority national vote and a majority in at least four of the six states. No referendum has succeeded in Australia without bipartisan support and this one – the country's first since 1999 – looks no different.

;

;The body, known as the ;Indigenous voice to parliament;, would be an independent advisory body on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, such as health, education and housing, in the hope that such advice will lead to better outcomes. The government has pitched the voice as a way for First Nations people to be consulted on laws that impact them, and has reiterated that there would be no obligation to act on the advice.

;
;

;;Related: ;;What is Australia's historic voice to parliament proposal?;

;
;

;But the political opponents have argued against the plan, claiming it would be divisive, legally risky, is lacking in detail, and say discussion around it has been marred by misinformation and conspiracy theories.

;

;The often vitriolic criticism seems to have had an effect. Over the past year, polls have shown a steady decrease in support for the voice's creation, with most recent surveys showing support falling well short of what is needed to win when Australia heads to the ballot on 14 October. The final YouGov poll, published on Thursday, puts support for the no camp at 56%, against 38% for yes.

;

;At times, the campaign has revealed the racial divides which still exists in Australia.

;

;Last month, the conservative Indigenous senator and leading no campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price denied that Indigenous Australians continued to suffer negative impacts from colonisation.

;

;“I'll be honest with you, I do not think so. A positive impact, absolutely. I mean, now we have running water, readily available food,” ;she said in widely condemned comments.;

;

;The yes campaign has also been battered by the Blak sovereignty movement, which has led the progressive no case, arguing the voice would be powerless while pushing for truth and treaty to come ahead of constitutional recognition.

; ;

;The no campaign has leaned heavily on the slogan “If you don't know, vote no”, which former high court justice Robert French ;described as; an invitation to “resentful, uninquiring passivity”.

;

;“It does not require a black armband view of history to conclude that colonisation did not bring unalloyed benefits to our First Peoples,” French said. “Nor does it require rocket science logic to conclude that we live today with the cross-generational effects of that collision.”

;

;The yes campaign, meanwhile, has pointed to the past as to why voters should vote yes. The Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, spent part of the final campaigning week in the nation's centre, Uluru, ;where the proposal for the voice was first formally presented in 2017.;

;

;Sitting with senior traditional owners in central Australia, Albanese said Australians; had an opportunity to “lift the burden of history;” and move forward with a positive vote on Saturday.

;

;“I believe Australia can rise to the occasion between now and 14 October,” he said.

;

;“We have just … days now in which Australia can be an enlarged country, a country at peace with our history, a country more unified, a country able to move forward, in the words of the Uluru statement itself, walking together for that better future.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;The Guardian view on Australia's Indigenous voice referendum: a yes vote is a clear step forwards;

;
;

;The referendum was one of the first commitments Albanese had made upon winning the election in 2022.

;

;The bruising campaigns conclude on Saturday, when voting booths close and the count begins. Attention is slowly turning to the aftermath of the referendum result, and what a no vote would mean for the nation.

;

;Labor senator Pat Dodson, known as “the father of reconciliation”, gave a speech on its impact in the last days of the campaign.

;

;“If we say no, then obviously that's going to be [a] matter for us to reflect upon,” he said. “We need to look in the mirror and say who the hell are we, what have we done, and what are we going to do about it.”

; ;

;Leading yes campaigner and Indigenous activist Noel Pearson said ;a no vote would 'bring shame upon us';, while prominent Indigenous leader Marcia Langton said it ;would have long-lasting consequences for Indigenous people.; Both have said they would withdraw from public activist work in the event of the referendum failing.

;

;Langton says: “I fear a no vote will be interpreted – and falsely, I should say – as a mandate for governments to do nothing and to make our lives worse.”

;

;“Many Indigenous Australians who are on the frontlines of dealing with these problems in towns and cities and communities and outstations and home lands are very worried about the prospect of losing the voice because they already have little say, and a loss will mean that they have even less.”

;Judges have been told to delay the sentencing of convicted criminals currently on bail – including rapists and burglars – because prisons are full, according to a report.

;The guidance came from the senior presiding judge for England and Wales, Lord Justice Edis, on a private call with senior crown court judges, ;according to the Times;.

;

;

;A senior crown court judge was quoted by the Times as saying that, from Monday, judges have been “ordered/strongly encouraged” not to jail someone who appears before them.

;

;They were said to have added that the “biggest concern” was defendants charged with historic rape or rape of a child under 13 and other sexual assault, as even if convicted they were now likely to remain on bail.

;

;The prison population stood at 88,016 last week, an increase of more than 6,500 in a year, almost 10,000 up on two years ago and close to the capacity of 88,667. Last year, the government ;announced Operation Safeguard, the emergency use of 400 police cells ;to hold inmates.

;
